I faced fingerprint scanner issues with my lg v10 several times.. 
It was working fine and suddenly it no longer works/ accepts my print... 
follow these steps, 
1)Goto settings -> fingerprint&security -> fingerprints -> then delete all fingerprints 
2)Then goto apps -> switch to show system apps(I'm using 6.0) -> find com.lge.fingerprints then remove data and cache memory, and also remove data in lge.lockscreensettings.. 
3)Goto storage & USB -> clear cached data 
4) Then restart your mobile 
5) After that, add fingerprints in fingerprint lock 
then it detects your finger.. 
I tried it, worked fine with me.. 
again it doesn't detect your finger, repeat the steps.. 
no need to factory reset.. 
Hope this helps..

What's with the back cover material?

it's the processor, the Snapdragon 808. Both the G4 and V10 have it and it gets very hot and causes sluggish performance and eventually, it can even cause premature failure. I had a G4 as an insurance replacement for my G3 (grrrr) and it was shit, but I ditched it within 4 months for a V10 on my AT&T upgrade plan. That was a mistake as the V10 is plagued with the same shitty processor. I went through two replacements (one warranty, one insurance) before I got AT&T to give me a V20 insurance replacement instead. The V20 is A LOT better. I have had it for two months and the battery is still decent (not compared to Samsung, but on well) and when I am not seriously using it, it is very cool, even icy, to the touch. I love it.

The V10 and G4 both have defective processors. The configuration of the Snapdragon 808 in both phones leads to overheating and sluggish performance. Overheating over time leads to premature hardware failure. After I dropped my G3 in the toilet, I got an AT&T/Asurion insurance replacement. It was a G4 :(  
My G4 became sluggish and hot within the first 3 months. So much so that the following February, I went out and got a V10 on my upgrade plan. Oh boy, was that a mistake. While the V10 was packed with more features and power than the G5, it had the same damn faulty processor as the G4. I went through two replacement V10's (3 phones), one warranty and one insurance. I cannot stress enough that I DO NOT RECOMMEND this phone.

I have been using this phone for about a year now. The Verizon version, running marshmallow. All I can say is that it's a fantastic device. Blazing fast. A multitasking behemoth. Talk about audio, amazing. Screen is razor sharp, large and wide enough for me to chat, type emails and play games. The phone itself is so rugged and strong. Built like a tank. Battery is removable. Talking about battery, just install greenify and switch off your GPS, NFC and set screen brightness to 50 percent and you are good. Besides I have a spare battery so I'm always ready for anything. Bottom line, I don't need any other phone this 2017. What would samsung galaxy note 8 or iPhone x give me that this phone can't? It's just all a waste of money. I'm really enjoying my v10 in 2017.

You won't see much peformance difference. Unless you're playing heavy games. Those 4 1440mHz cores are still good performers and will be enough to provide fast and smooth multitasking experience on day-to-day basis. Plus, there will be less overheating. It is not guaranteed that a v10 with new serial won't bootloop. But disabling the big cores is a tested and proven solution as those big cores are responsible for bootloop. Take those cores out of the equation and you won't ever have to worry about the bootloop issue.

It is totally worth it. To avoid bootloop, you will have to root the phone and disable it's two big cores using Multi-core CPU Control app. So make sure you get the variant that is easily root-able and preferably bootloader unlocked.

I love my V10. It's sure not perfect but I love it. Nice camera.. I love the dual cam setup, it is not that good in low light conditions but you have option for screen flash so selfies will not be a problem if your ok with a little to very noisy shots. There's a screen retention problem but it can be fixed by installing screen deeming apps like s-filter or anything similar. It does heat up when playing games so this is not for heavy games. Battery is weak though, but when phone's not in use turning the battery saver feature on really helps. There's occasional lags but bearable, it's not that bad given the chip in it. my unit sometimes have issues with the screen rotation, it could be with the app (MX Player) as it doesn't happen when using VLC or the built-in video player. I never had problems with Network signals. 2G, 3G, and 4G works well. finger print sensor is ok, sometimes it doesn't read my finger print right away but after 2 or tries it's good. There are times that the Finger print sensor doesn't work so I need to type in my PIN to unlock it. One more problem with the battery, when the battery level reached 15% sometimes it just dies at 15% battery level. The UI is very friendly. I don't know why alot of people don't like the LG UI but I, personally, likes it very much. I just wish there's more options with customization. Overall, I love this phone. I just wished it don't get bootlooped soon. I'm still waiting for Nougat update. I heard it will come by 2nd quarter of this year. How about you guys? How's your experience?

Yes. SlimPort and MHL are competing standards.
 
MHL is more common. You can get the cable pretty much anywhere. It will only connect to HDMI.
 
SlimPort is supported by LG and Google Nexus. It will connect to HDMI or even (with the right cable) old VGA monitors, DVI or DisplayPort. You will likely have to acquire the cable from a well stocked Internet retailer. The cable doesn't require a power source, but if you have one handy, it can supply power to your phone. But it won't quickcharge, so this only slows down how fast your battery drains.

Go For Note5,If You Dont Have Budget Problem. 
If You Already Buy It, 
Then Here Are Some Tips To Take Care Of Lg V10: 
------------------------------------------------­---------------------------------- 
I have 12 spare batteries. I paid about $10 each. I dumped the back cover and simply use  
the Obliq case, the battery stays in fine. the case comes off very easily as well. 
the trick to getting the best battery life is A) not to use the same battery two days in a row,  
B) not to charge the phone overnight and C) not let the battery fall below 30%.  
all of these bad habits kill the battery. instead of plugging in the phone to charge the phone 
 I just swap in another battery. I leave the house with one spare battery in my radix one slim  
wallet just in case I run out of juice. I keep a spare in the car and a few on my desk at work. 
 all my settings are on full blast, my screen is at full brightness. 
------------------------------------------------­------------------------ 
Some tips. To avoid image retention (ghosting) issue, you can install Nightly app from Play Store and  
set its value at 80. If the display seems dim, use Lux Lite app to adjust and link the brightness to  
your preference. I have been using this combo for a month now and haven't seen a single ghosting issue.  
Secondly, I believe the key to bootlooping is to not let your device overheat. You can use CPU-Z app to  
keep an eye on cpu temps and make sure the temperature does not go over 55c. Use Greenify to hibernate  
unwanted user and system apps, it definitely improves battery life and minimizes drainage. Use CPU Spy  
app to make sure that your device is going into sleep mode. If not, then there might be an app preventing 
 deep sleep and draining battery; find it and Greenify it. Last but not least, disable Game Optimizer  
from battery settings and it is also a good idea to clear all apps cache and restart the device once  
in every couple of days. 
------------------------------------------------­------------------------- 
Backup Your Data Always. 
------------------------------------------------­-------------------------
Go For Note5,If You Dont Have Budget Problem.

Some tips. To avoid image retention (ghosting) issue, you can install Nightly app from Play Store and set its value at 80. If the display seems dim, use Lux Lite app to adjust and link the brightness to your preference. I have been using this combo for a month now and haven't seen a single ghosting issue. Secondly, I believe the key to bootlooping is to not let your device overheat. You can use CPU-Z app to keep an eye on cpu temps and make sure the temperature does not go over 55c. Use Greenify to hibernate unwanted user and system apps, it definitely improves battery life and minimizes drainage. Use CPU Spy app to make sure that your device is going into sleep mode. If not, then there might be an app preventing deep sleep and draining battery; find it and Greenify it. Last but not least, disable Game Optimizer from battery settings and it is also a good idea to clear all apps cache and restart the device once in every couple of days. Have a nice day!

My V10 did just that last night -- it froze, and it shut itself down. When I try rebooting it, the screen will show just the LG logo, and the operating system won't boot. Putting the device in the fridge is a temporary fix -- the phone will stay on for about 10 minutes, then crash again and bootloop eternally. Fortunately my phone is still under manufacturer warranty, and I will be getting a brand new replacement phone tomorrow. I love this phone so much. Too bad it has this nasty defect. I faced fingerprint scanner issues with my lg v10 several times.. 
It was working fine and suddenly it no longer works/accept my print... 
follow these steps, 
1)Goto settings -> fingerprint&security -> fingerprints -> then delete all fingerprints 
2)Then goto apps -> swith to show system apps(im using 6.0) -> find com.lge.fingerprints then remove data and cache memory, and also remove data in lge.lockscreensettins.. 
3)Goto storage & usb -> clear cached data 
4) Then restart your mobile 
5) Aftr that, add finerprints in fingerprint lock 
   then it detects your finger.. 
I tried it, worked fine with me.. 
again it doesnt detects your finger, repeat the steps.. 
no need to factory reset.. 
Hope this helps..

You probably have a faulty device, like all manufacturers produce. But I have my V10 for 4 months now also and I don't have the slight issue with it. Even more, I made an unwanted drop test, which kinda scared me at the time it happened. It fell faced down from hip height and like 2m forward. It was sliding nicely on the floor. I don't have a tile floor or a concrete one, it is made of wood, but still hard as hell. Before I picked it up, I honestly thought the screen was shattered completely, because the noise at the impact was really loud. I have only minor scratches here and there on the screen, because I don't use a screen protector or any case, because it makes my phone bulky. Yeah, probably it should have stood up to those scratches too, but I thing I had some tough microscopic debrees on the floor, and the Gorilla Glass 4 can't resist that much.
 
All in all, it's a very good phone, the camera is great, the screen also, it feels amazing in your hands, and when you first see it you will remain speechless, especially if you buy the white version. In terms of battery usage, I charge it daily, but the QHD screen drains a lot of battery when in use, so this is normal.

Hi - used the V10 for 10 months:
 
Bad: 
1) Am on my second warranty replacement device through AT&T, so am on device #3. 
2) Phone goes dormant and stays on the LG screen - there is a software issue - called a software loop error. 
3) Phone runs extremely hot while on battery and also when charging. 
4) Back cover is delaminating from the heat.
 
Good: 
1) Physically durable. 
2) Great screen. 
3) Excellent picture quality.
 
Lessons: If you use this phone as your everyday smart device make certain you have a backup device handy,and be on the cloud, as it will just die without any warning signals other than the flashy type of heat the phone puts out - the sides of the phone get really hot and then it dies. LG V10. Just LPDDR3-RAM but 4 GB. 
A perfectly robust and gripped back design. 
The camera is placed in the middle for symmetry, but the corner would be better. 
The laser auto focus blaster could also be used for distance measurement with third-party applications. That could be very useful.
 
But their camera-application is a dream. It uses that second screen very well, and has many features. It might not be the fastest, and the burst shots are limited to thirty, but you can set framerate and bitrate and video resolution INDEPENDENT from each other. Every power-user dreams about that. Bitrate settings were possible previously on the Galaxy Note Two on Samsung, which was in 2012. There were quiality settings of low, middle and high. Low 1080p-video was equal to high 720p-video. Both were around 12 megabits per second. The V10 has no 5.1-Microphone, but the pro-mode displays the audio input from both microphones and gives you full control about photos and videos, which makes one feel like a real professional user. Additionally, pausing is supported in all modes (even slow motion), and it might be limited to 120fps, and there is no zero pause lag (known from Nokia 108, Samsung GT-i8000 and TouchWiz Camera v5.0 and higher), but I am looking forward to 2160p@60fps on phones in 2017. With 1440p@120fps, you can slow down to half, and yet have sixty frames per seconds TO SPARE. With ¼, you have 30fps instead of 15fps to spare. 15fps is the grey zone of enjoyability of videos.
 
A physical shutter key is missing, (it could be used by applications such as games too, but would make shooting more convinient), but it has tap-to-shoot. Something, which Samsung removed in 2015 on their S6.
 
There is no way to launch the camera quickly with a physical shutter button, but the secondary screen can be used in a very similar way as the toolbox from the S5 and the Alpha, and the Edge-Screen of the .
 
3000 mAh for such a power-user-phone might be slightly too low. The iPhone 2g was tvelve millemetres thick, and nobody had a problem with that. With that thickness, the V11 or V15 or V16 or V20 might achieve 6400 mAh (according to my calculations). 
Maybe, Samsung and LG could build together the ultimate power user phone, which contains the feature range from all phones. All sensors, all hardware, all features, and all capabilities, as long as it is possible. And maybe some additions (e.g. Dual IR blaster and reciever for 3D-aiming) and maybe a sligh optical zoom, if there are no external moving parts and other problems, ugly compromises(,) with camera hardware.

I have had this phone for about 5 months now, and I must say, it is, hands down, the best phone I've ever had. The 64GB of internal storage is more than enough for me, but the added SD slot is nice to have. My games run smoothly and look incredible on the large screen. The overall screen resolution is just incredible. When paired with the great cameras, my pictures and videos look so sharp. This allowed me to get a lot of great pictures of my sister's wedding. The battery does tend to die out rather quickly, but the quick charge plug and replaceable battery are more than enough to balance that out. For sheer performance, this phone cannot currently be beaten. The sturdy build does it's job as I've inadvertently dropped it a few times with only minor cosmetic damage. This prompted me to find a good case to augment the sturdy build of the device. I went with a Zizo case which is not only tested to meet military standards, but, also fits my style quite well. Overall, a modern masterpiece. 5/5 stars.

I've been using the LG V10 Dual SIM since February. After travelling with this phone, these are the areas of improvement. 
 
1. Needs at least 5-7 hours screen-on-time, 18 hours standby time.  
2. Aggressive battery management like Sony's Stamina modes.  
3. UI isn't smooth, slows down at times. Nova helps here. 
4. Notification LEDs, front and back. 
5. Dual front speakers, front+rear firing like LG G4s, that can play up to 90dB without distortion. It's currently 90dB with distortion. 
6. Hybrid - Phase detect & laser auto-focus. 
7. Low light front camera f/1.7 with manual controls for stills/video. 
8. Dual SIMs should be default - No more single SIMs. Save on development resources.

I just got the V10, been using it for the last couple weeks.  I'm liking it a lot.  The basic specs that attracted me were the swappable battery, SD card support, good camera with OIS, and solid fingerprint scanner.  I've really gotten to like the second screen too, not a requirement for me but definitely appreciate that it's there.  The 16 MP camera hits a nice sweetspot to me, I'm not chasing megapixels and this is the max size I can freely store in Google Photos.  The 4 GB RAM is nice and roomy, the Snapdragon 808 is fine, not super speedy and there are occasional hiccups in the UI but nothing I would explicitly point out as an issue.  Definitely would prefer a "V11" with the 820 but there's honestly nothing out there right now with the same specs that I require (see above).
 
The QuickCharge 2.0 is a godsend, I advise everybody to avoid any charger slower than that.  I also added the wireless charging back for easy top ups since I already have wireless chargers lying around, much slower but so convenient.  Battery power is average to good on Marshmallow, standby seems to last forever (maybe due to the new Doze feature in MM) but screen on time seems just average to good.  This phone is BIG.  It's slightly larger than my Galaxy Note 3 with a slightly smaller screen due to the system buttons being placed at the bottom of the screen.  The thing is also built like a tank and thus much heavier than other phones, a reasonable trade off but it is noticeable.
 
I have yet to have any bootloop or other software issues.  I do wish there was more third party ROM support as the hardware is very nice, I'd like to keep it around for a good while.

First LG phone, and was bought with trepidation due to all the QC issues from LG products in general...until lately. The G4 and G5 user reviews from acquaintances that have had them expressed the same opinion with Samsung phones, which I have sworn by until their switch to a sealed form-factor with no removable battery or SD card slot with the Note 5/S6.  
Then again, the only Samsung products I have ever owned were a Note 2 and 3, and never their low end products. 
 
The nags were few and all but one were negligible; the most obnoxious was the softkeys--I actually prefer 'hard' softkeys since they don't take up the phone's screen space (but the height of the softkeys are adjustable in the settings!). Installing an FM receiver but not allowing access unless rooted is another "Why?," since I live in an area where the weather fluctuates and we have power/utility outages during winter. The buttons take getting used to, and the fingerprint reader gets more confused as the phone's waketime extends past a week. 
 
Pros? Lots: The camera is awesome and I am in search for a tripod mount for a phone now; the pictures are stunning and the settings are on par with a good PointNShoot. The ruggedness of the phone just allowed me to get a rudimentary case and screen protector rather than the bodyarmor that my otterboxes offered for my Notes, required for their fragility. Battery life is good since I am one that uses Greenify and turn off radios if they're in poor reception or not in use. If in a poor reception area battery's usually 2/3rds empty with light use during a 8 hr workday, but the quickcharger is a lifesaver. Buy a Spare!
 
The boon was this purchase came with a LG Urbane 2 for free (but they left out that the callsharing feature for the watch was adding another line! Typical AT&T lying by omission). The two compliment each other pretty well, but the 'super' functions of this watch remain to be seen since its in its infancy.

I have had this phone for about 2 months now, and I must say, it is, hands down, the best phone I've ever had.  The 64GB of internal storage is more than enough for me, but the added SD slot is nice to have.  My games run smoothly and look incredible on the large screen.  The overall screen resolution is just incredible.  When paired with the great cameras, my pictures and videos look so sharp.  This allowed me to get a lot of great pictures of my sister's wedding.  The battery does tend to die out rather quickly, but the quick charge plug and replaceable battery are more than enough to balance that out.  For sheer performance, this phone cannot currently be beaten.  The sturdy build does it's job as I've inadvertently dropped it a few times with only minor cosmetic damage.  This prompted me to find a good case to augment the sturdy build of the device.  I went with a Zizo case which is not only tested to meet military standards, but, also fits my style quite well.  Overall, a modern masterpiece. 5/5 stars.

I have been using the phone for two months now and am really happy with it
 
Good 
1) The camera is amazing, and the manual mode is great. 
2) The secondary screen is really helpful 
3) The phone performs really well, and is great for multitasking 
4) The audio quality for headphones is really great 
5) The fingerprint sensor after the marshmallow update is really responsive
 
Bad 
1) The phone does heat up once in a while 
2) The battery usually does not last me all day, but quick charge ensures that i can always refill it asap
 
Overall, i would recommend this phone to anyone looking for a big screen phone. 
4.5/5

First, the bad, which is really a good....Mine died after charging it with the OEM charger and cable that came with it, was at a hotel and think their outlet was messed up. I contacted LG and they shipped it free and repaired it free and had it back to me within a week. It was like getting a new phone back. So major points to them for taking care of a power issue with the phone. Makes me very glad I went with them.
 
I love the phone. My ONLY complaint is that it doesnt have the option to keep the screen on while your looking at it. Like the LG G3. That option is a must with smart phones. I dont care that it doesnt have a notification light. As often as I check my phone, it doesnt matter.
 
Speed is great. It runs smooth. Battery life is also great. I think its much improved from my LG G3. My phone has also been updated to the latest android op sys. The fast rapid charge is AWESOME. Its crazy how fast the thing charges. I also have the second battery and charger cradle and have yet to use the second battery, which shows me that the battery life is great! Of course if you are on the phone constantly, your battery life will suffer no matter what phone you get. Just have your rapid charger and cable that comes with the phone handy and your good, otherwise get a power bank.
 
Main reason for getting this phone was the option to increase memory and the fact that I can change out the battery if it dies or goes bad. Cant do that with an iPhone. Running a 64gb micro sd card and it runs fast. Internal storage is 64gb as well. Lots of storage space! Coming from the LG G3 and enjoying that phone, this is a total upgrade. Very pleased and very satisfied with my purchase.
 
I would buy this phone again in a heartbeat if I had to, in fact I am actually thinking of buying a second one, just to have a backup. Thats how much I like this phone.

I use a camera too much for photos and videos, how is your experience about its all of thre camera both daylight and in low light and I watch a lot of movies in 1080p like you o smartphones, does the light bleeding of second screen disturb you while watching movies in pitch black like at night while lying on bed and when there is a Dark scene going on in the movie? hope you under stand my question.

Yes it has some back light bleeding in secondary screen. But you can only notice it when you are in pitch black and when you are not using the primary screen. 99% of the time it not noticeable at all. To be fare, it is expected to have back light in any LCD screen as they have to light the back panel entirely unlike Amoled. This doesn't mean V10 is lighting the entire panel; it's just the top portion. Hence a small back light is noticeable in dark. 
 
I am watching 1080p in the phone. It's almost as good as Note 5 to me.

The LG V10 is SO much better than the LG G4. It is a refreshed (better) version of the G4. I HAVE the G4, and let me tell you - the LG V10 is better in EVERY WAY, aside from maybe the pixels per inch, in the display, as it has a larger screen with the same resolution, which means the same amount of pixels are more spread out, in a larger surface, making things less crispy, but you won't notice that, at all - TRUST me.
 
The only other downsides would be that it has the same sized battery, despite having a larger screen, a bigger primary display, and an additional secondary display (dual screen functionality), on top of it, which is always on (the secondary, I mean), unless the phone is turned off completely (which will eat into the battery, which means - all things considered/remaining equal, the LG G4 has less things eating up the same sized battery), as well as the fact that the battery is non-removable, but when you consider the fact that the LG G4 comes with 32GB of internal storage, with an optional 128GB of additional Micro SD storage, and the LG V10 comes with 64GB of internal storage, with an optional 200GB of additional Micro SD storage, it means nothing, anymore.
 
And aside from that, it has 4GB of RAM, instead of the 3GB found on the G4, it has WAY better build quality, a better camera for video capturing, a second functional screen, better in-built sound for music (RIDICULOUSLY high quality audio), a six-inch display (though, larger size can also be construed as a bad thing, for/to some), among a whole HOST of other features, it just seems like a no-brainer, to me, as to the better choice, here.
 
Take it from me and go for the V10, buddy. V10, ALL the way.
 
Signing off/out,
 
Present G4 Holder

7. both H962 and H961n are dual sim.
 
I forgot to mention this point.

I just got the H962 model. Allow me to compare and contrast it to the H961N:
 
1.The H962 comes with a charger that has an American plug. The H961N comes with an asian plug and will require a special adapter if you use it in the United States. So the H962 has what you need to charge it right out of the box in the US.
 
2. The default language on the H962 is in english. The default language on the H961N is some asian language(probably Korean) and so when you boot the H961n up the first time the setup screen wont be in english. 
 
3. The H962 is not tied to any phone carrier. And so it has absolutely zero carrier bloatware apps and it also has absolutely no carrier tramp stamp on it. The H961N is tied to a Korean carrier (LG's Uplus carrier) and so you will see the Uplus stamp on the back of the phone, you will also see it on the boot up screen, and you will see plenty of korean language Uplus bloatware apps that will take an hour to uninstall. The H962 is the pure clean carrier free version and only shows the LG logo on bootup and has the LG logo stamp on the back. 
 
4. The H962 has an fm radio and comes with an fm Radio app installed on it. The H961N also has an fm radio with the radio app.
 
5. Both the H962 and H961n provide the same band support in the United States. Neither will support 4G in the US.
 
6. Both H962 and H961N have 64GB internal storage.
 
So with this, you can see that the H962 is the better variant to have over the H961n. NewEgg.com sells the H962 (they have it incorrectly listed as H961n, but it is actually H962). You can probably find the H962 at other online retailers as well.

I like my cellphones and have had quite the journey lately. Within last 2 years I have been through an iPhone5,G3,S6 and now the V10. I don't care much about benchmark scores and who has the most this and that. However I dont know why I went with the S6 last go around. I was actually there for the G3 and the nice look of the glass on glass s6 got me. The S6 wasn't bad but like a lot of people might admit,the change wasn't good. I was to used to the "no more side buttons" feel of the Lg and didn't like the setup of the Samsung. I used it for 6months while patiently waiting for LG's newest smartphone. Seen this and loved everything about it. I'm not even using a case which I love bc i like being able to hold the phones true sleep shape. Honeslty guys some of you need to eat your Wheaties bc I swear one of the VERY first things I said to myself in the car outside after purchasing it was "wow its bigger than my s6 but feels way lighter?"(idk,maybe the s6 was just as heavy and I'm used to it?I doubt it). Also the screen,i used to look at the dimensions on paper/screen of these 5"+ smartphones and think that it was just to much. But the way LG has done this 5.7(2.1 2nd screen) really doesn't seem to big at all and now I prefer these bigger screens to be able to see more. It's got this really cool feature where you can swipe across the bottom navigation icons and it will go into a one-handed operation smallest type screen. I have to mention how super slippery that S6 was in my hands and led to so many drops I had no choice but to purchase a case. This v10 with the rubber(actually Its made of a harder type material that is 5x stronger than plastic and feels like rubber) feels very good in my hands and provides the needed grip I need. The camera is just at the Top of the smartphone game,the s6's photos and videos were always so over saturated. Battery really isn't bad for me,some must be cranking up there brightness bc I leave mine on auto most of the time or 45%(doesn't sound bright but it is). Quick charging I don't know how fast it is exactly but it's pretty damn fast. Promo deal with memory card and battery charger a huge plus. Yea i can honestly say I learned my lesson and will be staying in the LG camp until I can find better. The only con I have found so far is the sound/speaker isn't the loudest. Its not bad sounding,just low. However,it has option for 32bit Hi-Fi when having headphones or speakers plugged in(so really not a con here). To me works out great bc wherever this phone goes 90% of the time my gear circle headphones are right along with it.  Yea whoever decides to grab one of these you won't be disapointed. Just waiting for my Marshmallow update now

LG V10 Fingerprint Scanner/Sensor.  One more thing.  Skin contact is not required on BOTH the SIDE RAILS.  As long as skin contacts a SMALL part of either of the SIDE RAILS. ...the Fingerprint Scanner/Sensor will work.  Good Luck finding a case.  I'm not having any luck finding one.

LG V10 Fingerprint Scanner/Sensor.  Apparently, your hands (rather skin, to be very specific) needs to touch the Stainless Steel SIDE RAILS of the phone for the scanner/sensor to work properly. Some people have claimed that "re-scanning" your finger after putting a case on solves the problem but it doesn't. Again, skin contact with the Stainless Steel SIDE RAILS of the phone is required in order for the Fingerprint Scanner/Sensor to work properly (if at all).  This issue may not occur with every LG V10 case. To verify this information yourself (if you have a V10, like myself) before buying a case... simply try to do a fingerprint scan while using some material to prevent your SKIN from touching the SIDE RAILS.  For my test, I used thin craft foam sheets.

How long your phone's battery lasts is very subjective. Everyone should know this, common sense, right ? How long does it take your current phone to charge from dead to 100% ? I haven't seen anyone post their own tests on charging time for their own phones. As for the validity of my tests, any other V10 owner can call me out on it, by doing a similar charging test.  Point is though, regardless of how long your phone lasts throughout the day....question is : Will your phone last you at least 3 hours of intense heavy use ?  If my phone can last me 5 hours (I'm underestimating here) ....no problem cause my 'second/extra' battery fully charges in approximately 3 hours (maybe less).  More than likely LG is using this "strategy" until better, improved & reliable (less costly too) Lithium Polymer battery technologies are developed. FYI, I live off-the-grid so battery life is very important to me.  Thank you LG, for giving me a free extra battery.  I really appreciate it alot.

LG V10 Second Battery Charging Test.  I again ran the phone (battery) dead.  It would not boot up and actually indicated a 0% charge.  After the first hour (exactly)  the battery was 38% charged.  After 2 hours (exactly) the battery was 95% charged.  Qualcomm Quick Charge wall adapter and a third-party data/charging cable was used.  Phone (battery) reached a 100% charge in 2 hours 14 minutes (exactly) . The phone remained off the entire time during this second test. That's a difference of about 45-46 minutes quicker than the first test (impressive and confusing, if you ask me). I didn't do anything different. I may do one more test but I'm confident with a two hours and thirty minutes 0% to 100% estimate.

Um, not sure about your question or intention of your comment. At first I felt like 3 hours was kind of too long a charging time (considering the phone was off the entire time). I'm not saying the screen was off, I'm saying the phone was off. Considering that I'll be part of the Promotional Offer (...extra battery, etc)...the 3 hours became a little bit of a relief because I highly doubt that my battery (in the phone) will drain faster than the 3 hours charging time required to go from 1%~100% for my spare battery. In other words, the spare battery helps ease my disappointment with battery life.  Besides, I also carry a (fully charged) 10,000mAh power bank, so no major concerns of running out of power.

Um..I'm writing a review TO anyone who owns (and hopefully loves) an LG Optimus G. 
This review is "specifically" for you guys (me being one of them).  I really really like the Optimus UI (original UI).  When I wrote a review about the Optimus G's UI, I stated in that review (3 years ago !) that it was the best UI I had ever experienced.  After using the V10 for several hours....LG felt like a COMPLETE and utter stranger to me.  In fact, I thought several times I was using Touchwiz (which I dislike immensely). I don't' regret' getting the V10 BUTTT I'm now desperately trying to figure out how I can get back the Optimus UI found on the Optimus G (E970).  I really don't know what to tell you other than what you should already know.  Handsome Rugged and Durable Design (body), Superb Camera, Fast and Flawless Navigation and Operation, Astounding and Breathtaking Display, battery (um, disappointing - sorry LG), AT&T's bloatware (minimal but I still think their dirty hands are hidden all over this phone)  I haven't tried features like : IR Remote, OTG capability, MHL or Slimport etc. but I know there's no (built-in) FM Radio App. This leads me to think there's no radio (oh well)   The LG V10 is definitely TOP NOTCH TECHNOLOGY. ...but the UI (in my honest opinion) has definitely taken a wrong turn. The Optimus UI is very intuitive (to me) but the LG UX 4.0+ (whatever '+' means) has now become a thorn in my hands for the next 2 years.  As awesome as this phone is, I honestly and sincerely would not recommend this device to any friends or family (solely based on the UI -sorry again LG).  If I figure out how to put the original Optimus UI on this phone, then I would label this phone : 2015 Smartphone of the Year (EASILY!!!!)  My other options would be :  Motorola Droid Turbo 2 or the Acer Predator 6 (or the next LG flagship .....um, possibly)

V10 certification information is up on the FCC website.
 
For whatever reason, the certification shows that t-mobile's UTMS band is not supported, confirming what is shown on gsmarena's specifications page. The certification also shows that a wireless charging cover will be available as an optional accessory -- the phone had to be tested and certified with the wireless charging cover on.
 
LTE bands 2, 4, 5, 7, and 12 are supported. There was no mention of LTE band 13. Since Verizon needs band 13, and since a Verizon model is pretty much confirmed, one would expect a second FCC filing for the Verizon model shortly.
 
It is unclear if the certification information that is up is for a t-mobile model or an at&t model or for both.
